titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
John Harvey Kellogg Papers, 1832-1965

did.abstract: Battle Creek, Michigan physician, food scientist, founder of the Battle Creek Sanitarium. Correspondence, student notebooks from University of Michigan and Bellevue Hospital, drafts of speeches and lecture notes, newspaper clippings and scrapbooks, and topical files; include material concerning medical theories and practices, especially matters of diet and hygiene, his work with organizations such as the National Vitality League, Race Betterment Foundation, Battle Creek Three Quarter Century Club, Chicago Workingmen's Home and Medical Mission, and Seventh-Day Adventists; also photographs.
did.langmaterial: The materials are in English; some documents in French and German.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Gertrude W. Goodwin (Donor No. 3506), secretary of the Race Betterment Foundation of Battle Creek, Michigan.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

altformavail.p: A microfilm edition of the Kellogg papers is also available. The microfilm edition is described in a separate finding aid.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., John Harvey Kellogg Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: John Harvey Kellogg, born February 26, 1852, earned worldwide acclaim in his lifetime as a health reformer and propagandist, and as head of the Battle Creek Sanitarium. Kellogg is now best known in connection with the line of breakfast cereal products made by the company that bears his name. While John Harvey Kellogg conceived the notion of flaked corn as a healthful morning repast, it was his brother, Will Keith, who turned his hand to the development of the breakfast food company. John Harvey Kellogg was also a skilled surgeon, an editor, and scientist who saw himself as primarily an educator determined to focus public attention on preventive medicine as the means to maintain good health. The main thrust of Kellogg's good health message was that vegetarian diet, regular exercise, fresh air, and sunshine are the keys to a long and vigorous life. Kellogg was a testament to the efficacy of his principles, living to age ninety-one and working diligently until succumbing to pneumonia on December 14, 1943.

Kellogg's father, a convert to Seventh Day Adventism, moved his family to Battle Creek when John Harvey was age four; thus the young Kellogg grew up well versed in the health reform principles of the Adventists. Many of these tenets, especially regarding vegetarianism and temperance, were elements of Kellogg's mature thinking on healthful "biologic living." Kellogg, an 1875 graduate of Bellevue Hospital Medical College, brought a solid training in orthodox medicine to his health reform efforts. In this, he differed from most earlier health reformers, whose systems often lacked grounding in science. Kellogg made repeated trips to Europe to keep abreast of developments in medicine, surgery, and physiology in order to buttress the scientific foundations which supported his health teachings.

Upon completion of his medical training, Kellogg returned as medical superintendent of the Adventists' Western Health Reform Institute in Battle Creek. Kellogg's vigorous efforts as a promoter and publicist soon brought the Battle Creek Sanitarium (as the Institute was renamed in 1876) to national prominence as "a place where people learn to stay well." Kellogg used the Sanitarium as a testing ground for the application of his "Battle Creek idea" on the effect of diet, exercise, correct posture, fresh air, and rest on the health and fitness of individuals. The program did enhance health. Kellogg and the Sanitarium prospered, despite policy differences with the Seventh Day Adventists, a 1902 fire which destroyed the building, and receivership debt due to overbuilding, until the 1930s Depression cut down patronage. In good times, Kellogg traded heavily on the celebrity of the Sanitarium's clientele to sell his health reform ideas. In hard times, he relied on the strength of the science which girded his system to keep pushing health. Throughout his sixty-seven year association with the Sanitarium, Kellogg never wavered in his faith in the rectitude of the "Battle Creek idea."

Kellogg was a prolific author and had a ready venue of publication in Good Health, a magazine he edited for nearly seventy years. Kellogg incorporated many of the ideas which appeared first as articles in Good Health into nearly fifty books. Included among them are: Body in Health, Colon Hygiene, New Dietetics, Plain Facts about Sexual Life, Practical Manual of Health and Temperance, and Rational Hydrotherapy. These books manifest Kellogg's efforts to bring the new medical science to the general public. Kellogg also lectured from coast-to-coast touring his message before as large an audience as possible. Finally, Kellogg's dynamic personality attracted disciples to Battle Creek to study at the feet of the master of "rational" medicine; these disciples in turn propagated Kellogg's ideas that medical science pointed to adherence to a vegetarian regimen of moderation as the surest way to good health.

scopecontent.p: The John Harvey Kellogg papers document the career of a medical doctor and health reformer and advocate. The collection provides telling insight to the operation of the Battle Creek Sanitarium. The papers span the years 1869 to 1965, with the bulk of the materials covering the years 1874 to 1943. Significantly, there are some collected published items in the collection that date as early as 1832. The Kellogg papers consist of correspondence, lectures, notes, memoranda, clippings, scrapbooks, notebooks, photographs, articles, and book manuscripts. These diverse sources provide ample documentation of Kellogg's life, and are an excellent source with which to examine early twentieth-century medicine in general and Kellogg's important innovations in health reform. The collection is also very strong on the development of the Sanitarium and the "Battle Creek idea" of natural health. Kellogg's zealous efforts to proselytize the world at large on the wisdom of the "Battle Creek Idea" are reflected in the papers. Also included are materials relating to his work with organizations such as the National Vitality League, Race Betterment Foundation, Battle Creek Three Quarter Century Club, Chicago Workingmen's Home and Medical Mission, and Seventh-Day Adventists.

The Kellogg collection came to the Michigan Historical Collections in two primary accessions, one in 1962 and another in 1972. Parts of the collection were reprocessed in 1988 prior to the entire collection being microfilmed. The collection is now divided into the following series: Biographical/Personal; Correspondence; Lectures, Speeches, and Related; Notes and Articles; Subject Files (medical missionaries); Clippings/ Scrapbooks; Bound Manuscripts/Published Volumes; and Photographs.

scopecontent.p: Biographical/Personal (0.1 linear feet) is a small series drawn from different parts of the collection containing summary information about Kellogg's life as well as some of the awards he received throughout his career.

odd.p: (Written reminiscences about Kellogg's life starting from childhood, both in prose and more fragmented notes. Also includes genealogical details and biographical sketches.)
(Awards, citations, nominations, and certificates given to John Harvey Kellogg.)

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (2 linear feet; 1875-1948) documents Kellogg's many interests and the operation of the sanitarium. Correspondents in the collection include C. W. Barron, Richard E. Byrd, Mary G. Edison, Irving Fisher, Clara J. Ford, Henry Ford, Margaret LeHand, Ernest G. Liebold, Chase S. Osborn, I. P. Pavlov, Gifford Pinchot, Hazen Pingree, Sir Horace Plunckett, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Franklin D. Roosevelt, Bernard Shaw, William Howard Taft, Ida Tarbell, Alexandra Tolstoi, Leo Tolstoi, Ilga Tolstoi, and Louis J. Van Shaick.

odd.p: (Letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg between 1875 and 1899. Mainly handwritten; includes letters from and to patients and colleagues, letters of introduction for research and medical work, and other correspondence. Includes a typewritten letter from Hazen S. Pingree (1840-1901).)

(Handwritten and typed letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg from 1900-1918. Consists of letters from and to patients and colleagues, letters of introduction for research and medical work, and related mateials, such as menus, programs, articles, and speeches. Includes a letter from Tatiana Souheline, daugther of Leo Tolstoy.)
(Handwritten and typed letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1919. Includes numerous letters to, from, and regarding Horace Plunkett.)
(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1920. Correspondents include family, friends, and colleagues. Includes letters of condolence regarding Mrs. Kellogg's death.)
(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1921. Includes numerous written requests for medicinal tablets and related items.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1922. Correspondents include Horace Plunkett, William H. Taft, and John D. Rockefeller. Also includes letters regarding the distribution of goods according to Mrs. Ellen Eaton Kellogg's will as well as a copy of the will itself.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1924 and 1925. Includes correspondence with Horace Plunkett, Ilya Tolstoy, Clarence Walker Barron, Ernest G. Liebold, and Ivan Petrovich Pavlov. Letters on both professional and personal matters.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg from 1926 to 1929. Includes a significant amount of correspondence with Clarence Walker Barron. Other correspondents include William J. Mayo, John D. Rockefeller, and Horace Plunkett. Letter regarding the Sanitarium, medical research and treatments, publications, products, and other matters.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg from 1930 to 1932. Correspondents include Horace Plunkett, Chase S. Osborn, Mary Stilwell Edison, Gifford Pinchot, Louis J. Van Shaick, Clara Bryant Ford, and Henry Ford.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1933 and 1934. Includes a significant amount of correspondence with Dr. Oscar H. Rogers. Also includes letters written to Margaret LeHand and President Franklin D. Roosevelt and correspondence with Prof. Irving Fisher.)
(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg, undated circa 1935 and dated January to June 1935. Correspondents include David Fairchild and Irving Fisher.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg, dated July to December 1935. Correspondents include David Fairchild, Irving Fisher, and Ivan Petrovich Pavlov. Topics include the Sanitarium, diet (meat, alcohol, coffee, etc.), and various health conditions.)
(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1936. Correspondents include Irving Fisher, Chase S. Osborn, Bernard Shaw, and Gifford Pinchot.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1937. Includes correspondence to Henry Ford, Clara Ford, and John D. Rockfeller. Other correspondents include Thornwell Jacobs of Oglethorpe University and Irving Fisher. Topics consist mainly of Kellogg's medical work and writing.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1938. Correspondents include Irving Fisher, John D. Rockefeller, Sir William Grenfell, Chase S. Osborn, and others. Topics include recommended treatments, dietary and temperance matters, and Kellogg's written work.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1939. Correspondents include Alexis Carroll, Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd, Irving Fisher, and Ida M. Tarbell. Also includes a letter to Alexandra Tolstoy. Topics include LD-Lax medicine and the Battle Creek Food Company, treatment recommendations, diet, and abstinence from alcohol and tobacco.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1940. Correspondents include Irving Fisher, Will Durant, Chase S. Osborn, and Ida B. Tarbell. Also includes a letter to Clara Ford. Includes recommendations for medical treatments and diet, as well as birthday wishes for Kellogg.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg in 1941. Correspondents include Charles William Dabney and other friends and colleagues. Also includes a letter from John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Topics include Kellogg's health as well as medical and dietary recommendations for others.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg fomr 1941-1948. Correspondents include Chase S. Osborn, Reginald M. Atwater., and others. Includes letters thanking Kellogg for his Christmas card and others conveying birthday wishes. Also includes letters and telegrams received expressing sympathy upon his death.)

(Typed and handwritten letters to and from John Harvey Kellogg, undated. Includes condolences on his wife's death, Christmas messages, and several responses to an event invitation. Also includes a diary entry from September 1911.)
(Handwritten letter from Oscar H. Rogers to John Harvey Kellogg, 23 March 1933.)
(Two clippings, one an advertisment for Battle Creek Health Products, and the other an article from the Detroit Free Press about attention to women's posture at Battle Creek.)
(Correspondence with four news clippings about alcohol, celebrations of longevity, and diet.)

scopecontent.p: The researcher will find the fullest development of Kellogg's thinking on any specific topic in the Lectures, Speeches, and Related Materials series (4.5 linear feet; 1875-1943). This series is arranged chronologically with each presentation listed.

scopecontent.p: The Notes and Articles series (4 linear feet; between 1890 and 1943) contains miscellaneous original and collected material, not always clearly identified, one portion of which is grouped together alphabetically by broad topic while another portion is arranged chronologically.

odd.p: (Collected articles, speeches, notes, etc. about alcohol, how it negatively affects health, and why it is not necessary in medicine.)
(Collected documents about causes and treatments for rheumatoid arthritis. Includes several copies of the "Battle Creek Program for Rheumatism.")
(Typed and handwritten documents regarding the Battle Creek Sanitarium, its approach, and its patients.)

(Documents, mostly typed, on biologic living, defining it, advocating for its adoption, and giving advice for things to include and avoid in one's diet in accordance with it. Also makes recommendations for behavior, such as exercising, using enemas, and sunbathing.)

(List of books in the Kellogg Library, arranged alphabetically by topic and with author, date, title, and call number information. Also includes an annotated bibliography of articles published from the Battle Creek Sanitarium Nutrition Laboratory since 1921.)
(Handwritten and typed documents, as well as sketches, about the circulatory system and how it relates to health practices.)

(Handwritten and typed documents about issues related to colon and gastro-intestinal health. Discusses the effects of diet and advocates for behavioral and cultural changes concerning bowel movements.)

did.unittitle: Diet for Special Age Groups and Special Cases

odd.p: (Documents about diet in relation to special conditions such as age or various diseases. Includes recommendations, recipes, etc. Mostly typed materials.)

(Typed and handwritten documents about diet, including both in terms of particular foods, such as milk or fruit, and general nutritional components, such as protein. Also information defining different kinds of diets.)

(Typed and handwritten documents about diet and nutrition. Includes sources on various nutritional elements (such as vitamins), their benefits, and potential sources; information on origins of "flesh-eating" and reasons to abstain from eating meat; and recommendations for specific diets.)

(Typed, handwritten, and printed documents on various diseases and treatments. Treatments include exposure to heat or light, exercise, surgery, and diet changes. Topius include fevers, high blood pressure, and other health problems. Also lists treatment recommendations for particular diseases, such influenza, appendicitis, and hysteria.)

(Typed and handwritten documents about patterns of dress in different countries and cultures. Focuses especially on the negative health effects resulting from women wearing corsets and other constrictive garments.)

(Typed and handwritten documents about education and schooling. Some relate to medical education, others to schooling children. Includes short, humorous anecdotes about schooling and education as well as formal correspondence and reports on the state of medical education.)
(Typed and printed documents about the use of electric current as medical treatment such as the application of a sinusoidal electronic current. Includes reports on cases studies.)
(Typed, printed, and handwritten documents about exercise and health. Includes materials listing and describing particular physical exercises and apparatuses as well as on the benefits of exercise.)

(Typed and handwritten documents about health and food. Includes materials on particular foods, such as soybeans or eggs, as well as categories, such as grains or meat. Also includes some commentary and recipes for particular dishes, such as vegetable soups or oatmeal.)
(Typed and handwritten documents on a variety of topics relating to health. Topics include housekeeping, diet, exercise, faith and positive thinking, and patterns of sleep.)
(Typescript of the Health Compendium. A collection of quotes and references on various health-related topics, including food, dress, auto-intoxication, and medical missionaries.)

(Typed documents with information and commentary on various historical figures in U.S. history, such as George Washington, Jonathan Edwards, Patrick Henry, or groups of people such as Native Americans.)
(Typed and handwritten documents about hydrotherapy. Describes various techniques, including baths and the use of hot and cold water in different conditions.)
(Typed and handwritten documents about living longer and old age, especially as it relates to health and behavior. Also material related to the three-quarter century club.)
(Typed documents describing exercises and multi-day exercise regimes for various ailments.)

(Typed documents about meat, tobacco, tea, and coffee, mainly advocating against them. Includes a typescript for a book on the meat-packing industry, as well as other documents about the negative health effects of meat, alcohol, and other substances.)
(Typed documents about "natural living". Advocates behaviors such as going outside, being in the sun, certain dietary considerations, avoiding worry, etc.)
(Typed and printed documents about health and the body. Topics include exercising, massage, eating, bathing, and sleeping.)
(Typed documents about politics and political figures such as Sir Horace Plunkett.)
(Typed documents with questions and answers from the Question Box Lecture series. Miscellaneous topics about health and medicine.)

(Typed and handwritten documents about race betterment, eugenics, and related organizations. Includes a 'Proposed Scheme for Race Betterment,' descriptions of 'race degeneration' advanced by various individuals and organizations, and related materials.)
(Typed documents about the practice of thermotherapy and heat's effects on the body generally and on specific organs and systems.)

(Typed documents with information about women's work and health as well as advice for various housekeeping tasks. Topics include pregnancy, table settings, household insect pests, and cleaning with water.)
(Miscellaneous typed, printed, and handwritten documents. Includes pieces of advice, poetry, and notes.)
(Typed and handwritten documents. Medical case statements, results of experiments (data collection tables), notes from trip to the middle east, and other items.)

(Typed, printed, and handwritten documents. Minutes of labor committee meetings, Mrs. E.E. Kellogg's test papers from the American School of Household Economics, letters and correspondence, and other materials.)
(Typed and handwritten documents. Includes Mrs. E.E. Kellogg's test papers from the American School of Household Economics and other miscellaneous materials.)
(Typed and handwritten documents. Includes notes on a visit to the Mayo clinic, various notes and memoranda, and John Harvey Kellogg's conversations with Count Tolstoy and Dr. Wiggam.)
(Typed and handwritten documents and on variety of topics, including high blood pressure, sleep, and health habits.)
(Typed and handwritten documents including pieces of advice, memoranda, and notes.)

scopecontent.p: Subject Files (1.3 linear feet; between 1885 and 1920) is arranged alphabetically by topic and relates primarily to Kellogg's interest in medical missionaries.

odd.p: (Typed and printed documents related to the American Medical Missionary College. Includes text of commencement exercises, opening exercises, lectures, announcements, and other items.)
(Typed and handwritten documents relating to the Battle Creek Sanitarium, including history, policies, and practices. Includes materials relating to John Harvey Kellogg's death and funeral.)

did.unittitle: Chicago Medical Missionary School (and Working Men's Home and Medical Mission) 1891-1907, undated

odd.p: (Typed documents related to the Chicago Medical Missionary School. Includes a list and lecture of "dark places of Chicago." Also included are meeting minutes and other descriptions of Chicago and missionary work.)

did.unittitle: Chicago Medical Missions: Chapel Talk and Announcement 1897-1898

odd.p: (Typed documents abut Chicago medical missions. Chapel talk from the dedication of the Chicago Medical Missionary Training School and other materials.)

(Typed documents relating to the formation of Christian Help Work Bands, including several lectures. These 'bands' were intended to provide spiritual and medical aid to the helpless and needy and also satisfy the material wants of supplicants.)
(Typed and printed documents related to the organization of the International Health Association, such as meeting minutes.)
(Typed documents related to International Medical Alliance, such as speeches given at meetings and the schedule for the annual session meeting or convention.)

did.unittitle: International Medical Missionary and Benevolent Association (Seventh-Day Adventist) 1894-1907, undated

odd.p: (Printed, typed, and handwritten documents related to the International Medical Missionary and Benevolent Association (associated with the Seventh-Day Adventist faith). Includes financial records, yearbook, and annual meeting records.)

(Text of a 'Medical Missionary Question Box' presented January 21, 1909 in conjunction with an Interdenominational Medical Missionary Conference in Battle Creek. Includes questions and responses with various individuals regarding medical missionary work and the nature and habits of foreign countries.)

(Patents include therapeutic lights, a massage apparatus, radiant heat baths, and improved irrigators. Legal papers include the will of Mrs. Ellen Eaton Kellogg and incorporation documents for Kellogg Schools. Also a petition regarding women's dress.)

(Typed and printed documents relating to the medical faculty. Includes minutes of a 1900 faculty meeting with complete text of a paper delivered by Kellogg as well as an 1898-1899 Battle Creek Sanitarium Medical Missionary Training School Announcement. This latter document includes yearly curricula, descriptions of courses and medical techniques and photographic illustrations of procedures and student attire.)
(Typed documents relating to the Medical Missionary Board, particularly board meetings.)

did.unittitle: Proceedings of Medical Missionary Conference and Convention 1905, 1911

odd.p: (Printed documents for the proceedings of the first Medical Missionary Convention in 1905 and the third Medical Missionary Conference in 1911.)

did.unittitle: General (Correspondence, resolutions, meeting minutes, etc.) 1895-1908, undated

odd.p: (Typed and handwritten documents relating to medical missionaries in general. Includes correspondence, meeting minutes, and lectures or articles.)
(Typed documents of lectures relating to missionary work in the medical field. Areas of the world mentioned include India, Arabia, and China.)
(Typed documents including lectures and question and answer sessions about topic related to medical missionary work.)

did.unittitle: Published Materials: news clippings, brochures, and 'The Medical Missionary' journal 1906-1909, undated

odd.p: (Printed materials including clippings, articles, and conference program. Consists mostly of accounts of medical missionaries and schools or colleges for educating them.)
(Typed and printed documents describing Mexican culture and medical mission initiatives there.)

did.unittitle: Michigan Sanitarium and Benevolent Association 1897-1899, undated

odd.p: (Typed and printed documents regarding the "Michigan Sanitarium and Benevolent Association," the successor organization Western Health Reform Institute and which was incorporated in 1897. Includes meeting minutes and articles of association for the group.)

did.unittitle: Sanitarium Training School for Missionary Nurses 1893-1907, undated

odd.p: (Typed documents relating to the Sanitarium Training School for Missionary Nurses and medical work in general. Includes graduation addresses and sermons for the school and information about the establishment and operation of various sanitariums ("Medical Missions and Benevolent Associations") in the United States as well as in England, Denmark, Mexico, and Australia. Also included are standard responses to be used in correspondence related to various inquiries about the Sanitarium and health care practices in general.)

did.unittitle: Sanitariums and "Medical Missions and Benevolent Associations" in the United States and Abroad 1893-1907, undated

odd.p: (Information about the establishment and operation of various sanitariums ("Medical Missions and Benevolent Associations") in the United States as well as in England, Denmark, Switzerland, Mexico, and Australia. Also included are standard responses to be used in correspondence related to various inquiries about the Sanitarium and health care practices in general.)

did.unittitle: Seventh Day Adventist Medical Missionary and Benevolent Association 1891-1897, undated

odd.p: (Typed and printed documents regarding the Seventh Day Adventist Medical Missionary and Benevolent Association, or the International Medical Missionary and Benevolent Association. Including meeting minutes, resolutions, and documents defining the nature of the organization in addition to various writings and information on its charitable activities and facilities (including orphans' homes).)
(Typed documents on the topic of the nature of the soul. Includes lectures, articles, and meeting minutes relating to this topic and other theological issues.)

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous (conference programs, "A Chewing Song" dedicated to Horace Fletcher, materials related to Richard E. Byrd's second Antarctic expedition, etc.) 1884-1943, undated

odd.p: (Assorted printed and typed documents. Includes various programs for conferences and other events, materials related to Richard E. Byrd’s second Antarctic expedition, sheet music for "A Chewing Song" (by "One Who Chews" dedicated to Horace Fletcher), and a program from Kellogg's funeral among other materials.)

scopecontent.p: The Clippings/Scrapbooks (2 linear feet; 1878-1952) consists of clipping files arranged both chronologically and by topic, and scrapbooks arranged chronologically supplemented by volumes pertaining to specific topics.

odd.p: (Newspaper clippings on various topics including the Battle Creek Sanitarium, other sanitariums, John Harvey Kellogg and his family, the temperance or prohibition movement, Dionne quintuplets, and other issues related to health.)
(Clippings, mainly magazine articles, about arthritis and various other health ailments. Includes information about the condition and advice about treatment, including dietary recommendations.)
(Clippings related to the Battle Creek College people, teaching, and events.)

(Clippings and articles about or written by the Battle Creek Sanitarium and those affiliated with it. Also includes some menus for meals at the Sanitarium and pamphlets about various Sanitarium programs.)
(Pamphlet, "The Biologic Life," by John Harvey Kellogg and a note from Will Durant.)
(Clippings with many images from health training at the Battle Creek Sanitarium. Shows various rooms and treatments.)
(Clippings and articles about John Harvey Kellogg's life, work, and death.)

(Clippings and articles about John Harvey Kellogg's theories and their applications with regard to health. Includes information about posture, physical treatments, exercises, and dietary recommendations.)
(Articles and pamphlets about living longer, celebrating long life with groups and organizations, and longevity in general.)
(Articles about medical missionaries, mainly within the United States. Includes several issues from the Medical Missionary periodical.)
(Articles and conference programs about race betterment and eugenics.)

(Articles about the three-quarter century club and similar associations celebrating reaching a certain age. Also includes articles about birthday celebrations for those with long lives, and general information on health and longevity.)
(Assorted articles and clippings on various topics, including the Battle Creek Sanitarium, one's "margin of safety", and prohibition.)
(Scrapbook pages with articles, photographs, programs, menus, ships' passenger lists, etc. Includes information on health, diet, Battle Creek and its anniversaries, and other meetings and events.)

did.unittitle: Various Subjects (including Kellogg and his death) 1904-1944

odd.p: (Scrapbook pages with clippings about John Harvey Kellogg (including his death) and Battle Creek Sanitarium. Many pages consist of multiple overlapping clippings.)
(Two scrapbooks composed mainly of clippings. The second is entirely composed of "Have a Smile" columns with jokes and various anecdotes.)

(Scrapbook composed of clippings presenting information about various sites in Europe, like Stonehenge or Cologne Cathedral. From "Hygenist Abroad" articles and various articles by Mrs. E. E. Kellogg.)
(Scrapbook composed of clippings of "Secrets of Good Health" articles written by Sir Arbuthnot Lane. Many address different dietary recommendations.)
(Scrapbook of clippings about temperance. Includes anecdotes and quotes from numerous individuals about the evils of alcohol.)
(Scrapbook of clippings about household work and housekeeping advice and techniques.)

scopecontent.p: Bound Manuscripts/Published Volumes (4.5 linear feet; approximately between 1869 and 1940) consists of various ledgers and daybooks, Kellogg's student notebooks, his professional notebooks, manuscripts of essays and other writings, and published works by Kellogg and others in the field of health and nutrition. The notebooks in particular manifests Kellogg's quick mind as student and as a doctor in search of the most recent trends in medicine and surgery. Not part of this Kellogg collection, but also available at the Bentley Historical Library, is a collection of Kellogg's published writings and the Good Health magazine.

odd.p: (Includes guestbooks with signatures as well as other materials, such as notes from readers of Good Health and alumni information files.)

did.unittitle: Various (primarily family materials): biographical materials, diaries, expense books, etc. circa 1885-1909

odd.p: (Handwritten account of Newell Carey Kellogg as a baby; expense books for various people including Agnes Kellogg, Lena Sargent, and Georgia Hartsough; data on Sheltland ponies owned by John W. Kellogg; unidentified diary entries; a "Time's Footprints" book; and other miscellaneous notes.)
(Accounts for membership in various organizations such as the International Tract Society or International Health and Temperance Association.)
(Accounts of expenses and money received for children. Separate accounts by child's name. Mainly lists items of clothing but also includes activities such as music lessons.)
(Household expense account book, 1897-1900. Lists individuals and their expenses in various categories.)
(Accounts listing food, clothing, cleaning and mending supplies, utilities, and payments to individuals.)
(Handwritten index for medical and health-related topics.)

physdesc.physfacet: Paper: 26 notebooks in 2 folders; Digital: .PDF and .ZIP files

odd.p: (John Harvey Kellogg's handwritten student notebooks related to mathematics, grammar, medicine, chemistry, and other subjects. Also includes a notebook of clippings related to science experiments.)

physdesc.physfacet: Paper: 41 notebooks in 3 folders; Digital: .PDF and .ZIP files

odd.p: (Handwritten notebooks. Includes various medical notes on various conditions and treatments as well as patient data. Also includes diary or calendar entries from 1912 and 1919.)

physdesc.physfacet: Paper: 11 notebooks in 1 folders; Digital: .PDF and .ZIP files

odd.p: (Handwritten notebooks. Includes various medical notes as well as diary entries from part 1896.)

did.unittitle: Topical File of Works by Kellogg or Battle Creek Sanitarium Doctors circa 1890-1940

odd.p: (Published articles on disease, diagnosis, and treatment by John Harvey Kellogg and others. Includes numerous articles from the Home Gymnasium. Several articles on posture.)

(Published articles on food and dietetics by John Harvey Kellogg and others. Includes articles on negative effects of alcohol, tobacco, sugar, meat, and other items, as well as positive recommendations.)
(Miscellaneous published articles by John Harvey Kellogg and others relating to health, medicine, science, temperance, etc. Several articles focus on particular scientists.)

(Published articles about health and medical institutions by John Harvey Kellogg and others. Includes information about Battle Creek, as well as more general information. Several articles focus on exercise.)
(Articles about iron as a nutrient by John Harvey Kellogg. Includes a chart with the amount of iron in various foods. Also information about the lime content of foods.)
(Typescript of the Health Compendium. A collection of quotes and references on various health-related topics, including food, dress, auto-intoxication, and medical missionaries.)

(Printed pages from 'Man the Masterpiece' by John Harvey Kellogg. Discusses eating, the art of chewing, the question of meat eating, sexual sins, sexually transmitted diseases, the dangers of alcohol and tobacco, general health advice and information on common ailments, and general life advice, for example on finding someone to marry.)

(Typescript of 'Nature's Remedies: A brief account of physiological methods of treating simple maladies.' Gives detailed instructions for various treatments involving water, heat, or electricity. Also includes specific information on particular health issues with recommendations.)
(Printed and typewritten fragments of various work on health, diet, eating habits, and other topics.)

(Articles and lectures on a variety of topics, such as food and diet, vegetarianism, herbal remedies, teaching and education, the political system in China, biographical sketches on several individuals, the New Deal, and other issues, including healtht and the body in general. Contains materials by John Harvey Kellogg and other authors arranged alphabetically by authors' surnames.)

did.unittitle: Van Noorden, Karl. Metabolism and Practical Medicine, circa 1907

physdesc.physfacet: Paper: 4 volumes in 2 folders; Digital: .PDF and .ZIP files

odd.p: (Typewritten notes or quotes from Karl Von Noorden's 'Metabolism and Practical Medicine'. Topics include diet, nutrition, properties of food, digestion, and other topics.)
(Printed works on the dangers of alcohol and other drugs. Includes articles by Lewis D. Mason, T. D. Crothers, F. C. Myers, C. T. Clark, and as well as issues of The Narcotic Review.)
(Printed works on the colon and gatro-intestinal tract by several authors. Includes numerous research articles by James T. Case, a professor of roentgenology (radiology).)

(Printed materials primarily on diet and food. Includes several articles advocating the consumption of meat, one from the Institute of American Meat Packers. Other articles discuss medical or dietary supplement fraud, such as that of Frank J. Kellogg.)
(Printed booklets on diseases and treatments by various authors; several in French.)

(Printed works including issues of 'Health Herald' and 'Good Words of the Christian Endeavor'. Examines a variety of concepts including the benefit of sun bathing, and recommendatios for different types of food.)
(Printed articles and pamphlets on eugenics and race betterment. Includes articles by Aleš Hrdlička, Gladys C. Schwesinger, and Edward J. Humphreys.)

scopecontent.p: The Photograph series (0.8 linear feet; between 1880s and 1940s) includes portraits and photos of John Harvey Kellogg with family and friends, other photos concerning the Battle Creek Sanitarium, its buildings and the activities that it administered, Kellogg's interest in a Chicago mission house, and Kellogg's travels. There are also family photos.

did.unittitle: Portraits of John Harvey Kellogg circa 1880s-1943

odd.p: (Portrait photographs of John Harvey Kellogg at several different ages.)

did.unittitle: Informal photos of John Harvey Kellogg (alone) 1919-1943, undated

odd.p: (Various photographs of John Harvey Kellogg outside on a path, beside a car or bicycle, or near a building, or inside sitting at a desk or the piano.)

did.unittitle: Informal photos of John Harvey Kellogg (with others) 1912-1943, undated

odd.p: (Photographs of John Harvey Kellogg with other people, mainly outside.)
(Photographs of John Harvey Kellogg by himself or with others, sent as Christmas cards.)

did.unittitle: Interiors and exteriors of Battle Creek and New York homes 1894, undated

odd.p: (Photographs showing the Battle Creek home and the rooms and furniture contained therein.)

did.unittitle: Kellogg Mrs. John Harvey (née Ella Ervilla Eaton) circa 1900-1915, undated

odd.p: (Photographs of Mrs. John Harvey Kellogg (née Ella Ervilla Eaton), by herself and with others, at various ages.)
(Photographs of John Harvey Kellogg or his wife with numerous children at various ages gathered around, young women holding babies, and children on horseback.)
(Photographs of John Harvey Kellogg in Africa and people there. Shows Kellogg interacting with people and animals, and sitting in the Garden of Allah.)
(Photographs of scenery and John Harvey Kellogg alone and interacting with groups of people.)
(Photographs of the Country Club Estates, John Harvey Kellogg and others outside in the surf, by trees and shrubs, and in horse-drawn carriages and automobiles.)
(Photographs of patients in Dr. Rollier's clinic in various settings such as performing physical activities outside in the snow.)
(Photographs of mission building exteriors, groups of people, and interior rooms.)
(Photographs of groups of children and adults in the Chicago slums. Also includes an image of homeless men sleeping in the police station.)
(Photographs and drawings of the Battle Creek Sanitarium building, people on the lawn, in the dining room, and outside on the piazza, and of the fire damage to the site.)
(Photographs of people at the Dedication Ceremony for the Battle Creek Sanitarium.)
(Photographs of the buildings for the Battle Creek Sanitarium. Includes the main building and numerous other such as the laundry and machine shop or hen houses.)
(Photographs of the interior of Battle Creek Sanitarium and several of its rooms such as a banquet hall or dining room. Photographs also show people sitting at the tables, standing by pillars, etc.)
(Photographs of various laboratories showing animals in cages, individuals analyzing various fluids, and classroom settings. Most images show lab attendants at work.)

(One photograph showing the exterior of a building with the sign 'Pavlov Physiological Institute of the Battle Creek Sanitarium', a man sitting on the porch, and several men in front of the porch with dogs on leashes.)
(Photographs of groups, mostly young people, exercising indoors and outdoors.)
(Photographs of groups of deer in semi-wooded area during several different seasons; part of a deer park on the grounds of the Battle Creek Sanitarium.)

did.unittitle: Various Sanitarium Events and Activities circa 1910-1943

odd.p: (Miscellaneous photographs of other Battle Creek Sanitarium activities such as lectures and conferences, cooking, laboratory work, and various treatments. Also includes an image of a float celebrating John Harvey Kellogg's Golden Jubilee.)
(Photographs showing groups of staff and faculty at Battle Creek.)
(Photograph of the exterior of the American Medical Missionary College building and a group photograph of the class of 1910.)

odd.p: (Photographs of various other men and women including John D. Rockefeller.)
(Miscellaneous photographs of groups of people, buildings, etc. Includes several with individuals dressed in Native American attire as well as scenes in France.)

odd.p: (Miscellaneous photographs of groups and crowds of people, buildings, etc.)

odd.p: (Album of photographs showing children's activities from the Sunshine Playground, including sunbathing, swimming, and lawn games. Also includes handwritten information about the results of medical examinations and the financial costs of the program.)
